channel.title: Vacuum weblog from Edward Vielmetti
channel.description: Recent content on Vacuum weblog from Edward Vielmetti

item.title: Game of Fail - HBO Now unable to host Game of Thrones premiere
item.description:
HBO Now is experiencing technical difficulties in hosting the premeire of the popular Game of Thrones season, according to multiple reports monitored on Twitter.

“Our team is working to resolve as soon as possible. Check back soon for updates.” @HBONowHelp, 9:26 p.m.

More news on this at Fast Company and (of course, where else) Reddit

The Reddit thread has lots of suggestions, some pointing the failure at HBO’s geolocation technology.

item.title: Taking a break from Facebook
item.description:
I’m taking a temporary break from Facebook.

You probably won’t read this message in time to switch any of your normal communciations paths with me; indeed, unless I had told you that I was leaving Facebook idle for a while you wouldn’t notice at all.

I’d prefer it if more people were blogging, and more to the point if I were blogging more. I miss the olden days when you could count on people updating their blogs more than once a month and when it made sense to make the rounds of blogrolls. But I suppose that’s just net.nostalgia for the olden days, the same way you might say that Flickr was better the first few years, and oh we don’t have anything quite like the Napster that we once had.

What we do have is Facebook, and plenty of it. A recent story somewhere that I read somewhere (see, this media makes our brains mush) was that people with Facebook accounts are dying, and that the Facebook we know now will be dominated some time soon by memorials to the dead.

Faced with that grim promise, what to do instead? Twitter is my solace, the endless stacatto chatter punctuated by weird Unicode glyphs, with cryptic tendencies and self-contained non-sequiturs.

I’m taking a break. How can you tell? I’m writing again. I don’t write on Facebook, so much as scroll endlessly and leave little obscure comments made out of mostly-remembered lyrics.

item.title: Roos Roast to add downtown Ann Arbor location
item.description:
Roos Roast is adding a downtown Ann Arbor location, due to open spring of 2016. The roastery on Rosewood will expand to a second location on E Liberty St, where Elixir Vitae used to be. Elixir will keep its Maynard St store open.

The interior construction in the store is going well, as far as it’s possible to determine from looking at the permit process and poking my head inside the door. So far the following permits have been pulled, according to the city’s eTrakit system:

BLDG16-0317 for demolition in the existing site, approved 3/7/2016

ELEC16-0449 for internal electrical wiring, approved 4/18/2016; work by Bremray Electrical

HDC16-062 to the Historic District Commission for a sign, applied 4/18/2016

PLUM16-0551 for plumbing, work by Chelsea Plumbing

SIGN16-0050 for an aluminum sign showing a hand holding a cup with the Roos Roast logo, applied 4/18/2016; the sign review is due 5/5/2016. Sign by Prototype Design in Tecumseh.

SOCC16-0024 for sidewalk occupancy, issued 4/21/2016.

The only piece of this process that looks like it could possibly go to a public hearing is the Historic District Commission determination of appropriateness of signage. If this were to be the case, a large orange poster would go up in front of the store to announce the meeting date.

A sign had been approved previously for the site in 2009 when the storefront housed “Organic Bliss”; at that point there was no requirement for anything more than staff approval of the signage. AnnArbor.com’s story about Organic Bliss closing in 2012 has a photo of the storefront at that time.

Previously in the news, see:

Deep-er Local on the Roos Roast website, February 2016

MLive story, March 1, 2016.

Ann Arbor Observer story, “Roos Roast finds new roost”, April 2016

item.title: Washtenaw restaurant inspections
item.description:
• Who: Wayne Eaker and the a2civictech Slack team
  • What: Restaurant inspections from Washtenaw County
  • Where: http://food-inspections.annarbortelegraph.com
  • When: As they are updated, up to twice a momth
  • Why: When you eat out, you care about food safety

Some example searches:

Three restaurants with 30 or more violations

Reports from 2016 of pest problems

The hardest part of this project is that it’s dependent on an undocumented interface from the contractor who does the work for the county.

One very nice aspect of the system that Wayne put together is that you can get alerts from every time a new inspection comes out that matches your saved settings, so you can track a particular restaurant or problem over time.

item.title: Prince
item.description:
Yesterday’s radio was full of the Prince music catalog. The artist passed away in his Minnesota home at the age of 57. In response any radio station that had anything other that pre-programmed music responded by playing his hits - “Little Red Corvette”, “Raspberry Beret”, “Purple Rain” - and the radio stations that had artistic control also played B sides, live shows, bootlegs and whatever they could find. Ann Arbor’s own WCBN was exemplary in this regard.

The radio that I remember is from the 80s when Prince’s music was in regular play on the Electrifyin’ Mojo’s show on Detroit’s WJLB. Prince did a very rare live radio interview with Mojo, and you can hear it in two parts - part one and part two - on Youtube.

What I haven’t found yet is the computer font with a perfect Prince symbol in it. You can get close by writing the prince symbol in unicode, or this ASCII representation may suffice: O(+> . But the real deal came on a 3.5” floppy disc from Warner Bros.

item.title: Milnor Time at Mr. Stadium
item.description:
My favorite laundromat is our nearby Mr. Stadium, which features enormous 5x load Milnor washers and corresponding supersize dryers, suitable for washing bedding.

Pellerin Milnor Corporation makes the equipment, and if you need to have industrial-sized laundry equipment, check them out.

Doing laundry in a laundromat lets you experience parallel processing first hand. It takes some minimum amount of time to run a laundry cycle, but if you can get all of your clothing and bedding into machines at the same time the total time to complete can be very reasonable.

As a bonus they have one of the few original Centipede arcade games in town, still taking quarters.

item.title: Earthquake in Ecuador, April 16, 2016
item.description:
Ann Arbor, MI, 17 April 2016: An earthquake hit near the coast of Ecuador on the evening of 16 April 2016. As of 1:00 p.m. Eastern time the current estimate is 235 killed and 1,557 wounded from the incident. Reports are still coming in from the hardest hit areas which lost telecommunications lines in the disaster, so expect these numbers to increase.

Early reports from Ecuador came in primarily via social media, as it took a while for the nation’s news organization to cut over to flash reporting of the news from their regularly scheduled programs. The country’s vice president, Jorge Glas, provided regular and authoritative reports on damage and emergency response.

Reporting on the damage was almost entirely in Spanish, as there is no substantial English language media presence in the county. I found the automated translation service provided by Bing in the Twitter feed to be indispensible. Some words that you will see over and over again:

  • personas heridas = people injured
  • personas fallecidas = people killed
  • sin luz = without electricity
  • sismo, terremoto, temblor = earthquake

For music and (sometimes) news from Ecuador, I turned to Tunein, which relays thousands of radio stations worldwide. At various times the following channels were interesting or informative:

  • Radio America Estereo, Guayaquil
  • Radio Quito, 760 AM
  • Ecuador Inmediato Radio, Quito

I looked for the shortwave broadcast of HCJB but it would appear that its English language broadcasts are no more. There is news in Spanish on the site under the Noticias banner.

Some individual news feeds to follow from the time of the event:

  • Lewis Shepherd, Washington DC based analyst
  • El Comercio, Quito newspaper
  • Mayra Pacheco, reporter for El Comercio
  • ECU 911 Quito
  • IG Ecuador, Instituto Geofísico with quake maps and scientific reports

Thoughts go out to everyone affected by the quake.

item.title: Reluctance
item.description:
For some reason that I cannot yet pin down I have been reluctant to blog on this site for the last few weeks. This is a slowdown after years of continuous writing.

It’s not so much writers block as simple avoidance; not so much sitting down with nothing to say, as not sitting down at all.

Writing is hard work, and there’s some natural inclination to gravitate towards writing work that is paid for to make that hard work pay. On the other hand there is some writing that will never be renumerative, but that wants to be written anyway.

At some point I am sure I will eventually give up on blogging, but I am reluctant to say that this is that week or month. Until then, the minimalist goal is to produce something enough that no month goes without some measure of content or discontent.

item.title: Yo
item.description:
The small experiment: post the smallest amount of text to two separate social networks, see what the differences are.

As I might have expected, Twitter generated fewer responses, and Facebook generated more.

I’m not sure that there are any conclusions to be drawn that are useful, as neither system is necessarily “useful” for individual messages in isolation. It’s the cumulative effect of being able to reach out to people that makes some value of them both.

item.title: Upgrade to El Capitan
item.description:
I’m working through the details of an upgrade from Mavericks to El Capitan. Some running notes.

The upgrade took about 2 hrs. I went to the Apple Store at Briarwood in Ann Arbor to get the install done, since their Internet is faster than my home UVerse.

After doing the upgrade the next big slow task is brew update. You would not be surprised to know that I have a lot of packages installed, and that brew is working hard to update everything.

The biggest reason that I upgraded was to get xhyve and thus Docker for Mac. I’m using the beta now (beta 5) and have gotten a few trivial things to work, but am still sorting out a few questions which might or might not be issues.

item.title: Stadium Boulevard project bids high, portions of project to be delayed
item.description:
The bids for the work came in higher than expected, so the City of Ann Arbor’s Ann Arbor Stadium Boulevard road reconstruction project will likely omit the section between Main Street and Seventh. That’s the word from the city’s engineer on the project, Michael Nearing, P.E. He writes in an email sent from his iPhone on Saturday, Feb 13, 2016 at 1:26 PM:

At this point it appears that the only realistic option to perform the project with the funds that are available is to revise the project limits. We are currently reviewing the plans, the planned work, our material choices, proposed construction methods, and the bid prices received to determine the most prudent course of action.

Once we better understand all the factors that will affect the work, we’ll share the information with Council and the public of our revised course of action.

We are hopeful the we can re-bid the project later this year and start construction after the U of M Home Football season.

Details on the city’s Stadium Boulevard Road Reconstruction Project page do not yet reflect this new reality, and the agenda for the February 16, 2016 Ann Arbor City Council meeting also does not include an agenda item on this topic.

item.title: Chicken and onion curry
item.description:
Saveur Magazine has a recipe for a chicken and onion curry from January 27, 2010. It took a little more than an hour to cook, but the results were very much worth it - delicious, and worth repeating.

We had the meal with rice, kale, and a daikon raita from food.com that I kind of liked but which was not a big hit with the rest of the table.

The current meal planning regime here uses a Google calendar and a question at the end of every meal: do you want this again, and how many weeks before we have it again? This curry will repeat in 3 weeks.

item.title: Ann Arbor Public Schools respond to social media threat
item.description:
Ann Arbor, Michigan, January 25 2016: The Ann Arbor Public Schools issued this news release and letter to parents, signed by Superintendent Jeanice Swift.

Monday, January 25, 2016

Dear AAPS Parents,

As many of you may have already heard, there have been threats made on social media to multiple school districts across the metro area, extending to Florida, and rumored to have occurred as far as California.

Please be assured that in the Ann Arbor Public Schools, we take any and all threats very seriously and consistently follow established emergency procedures in cooperation with Ann Arbor Police Department and other law enforcement agencies.

We received information in the early morning hours that Ann Arbor was included in this social media situation. Police were notified immediately and we have been actively working with the AAPD since first learning of this issue.

Our principals were advised early this morning of this situation, and we continue to work with law enforcement officials as part of our safety protocol. We will continue to monitor this situation very closely.

As the use of social media for posting threats against schools seems to be increasing, I would like to ask all parents to talk to their children about using social media and instruct them that if they see anything on social media that is a concern, to immediately report it to an adult, such as a parent, principal or teacher. If they re-post or pass on the threat, they can also be held responsible for issuing a threat and can receive disciplinary action as a result.

Please be assured that we take every threat seriously as safety for our students and staff is our first priority.

Sincerely,

Jeanice K. Swift, Ph.D. Superintendent of Schools

###

item.title: M7.1 earthquake felt in Anchorage, Alaska
item.description:
Ann Arbor, 6:35 a.m. Eastern, 2:35 Anchorage time: Local news coverage of the earthquake:

  • Strong earthquake felt throughout Southcentral Alaska, Alaska Dispatch News
  • Alaska Earthquake Center is @AKearthquake on Twitter
  • Municipal Light and Power @MLandP is an area electric utility
  • KTUU Channel 2 reports “Strong earthquake with initial magnitude of about 7.1 hits near Pedro Bay”

Ann Arbor, 6:30 a.m Eastern. A note on time zones: Anchorage is GMT-9, or 4 hours behind Ann Arbor time. The current time there is 2:30 a.m., and the quake hit at about 1:30 a.m. local time.

Ann Arbor, 6:20 a.m. Eastern: The Chugach Electric power outage map shows 3858 subscribers without power out of 28112 served mostly to the south of Anchorage.

Matanuska Electric Association is reporting via Facebook that about 4000 customers are without power due to the quake.

The earthquake at 1:30 am caused several outages including our entire Douglass substation in Willow and several other feeder outages, especially impacting the Palmer area. Crews have been called in from home to assess the situation and restore power.

Ann Arbor, 6:01 a.m. Eastern: The quake is now reported as a M7.1 - 83km E of Old Iliamna, Alaska, according to the USGS report. The did you feel it report from USGS notes that the quake was felt most strongly in Anchorage, Homer, and Kenai AK, and could also be felt by some as far away as Fairbanks AK and Whitehorse, Yukon, Canada.

Ann Arbor, MI, Sunday, January 24, 2016, 5:43 a.m. Eastern: A magnitude 6.4 earthquake was felt in Anchorage, Alaska. The quake’s epicenter was located 162mi SW of the city, according to the USGS report.

My high school classmate Mary Beth Hammerstrom alerted me to the quake on Facebook.

“Holy hell that was a big one!!!!!!!”

The NWS PACIFIC TSUNAMI WARNING CENTER reports in a bulletin of 1043 UTC that “BASED ON ALL AVAILABLE DATA… THERE IS NO TSUNAMI THREAT BECAUSE THE EARTHQUAKE IS LOCATED TOO DEEP INSIDE THE EARTH.” The quake was reported by USGS to have been at a depth of 65 miles.

item.title: Writing things down
item.description:
I have a series of paper notebooks that I keep meeting notes in. I’ve settled on the Roaring Spring 100pp 5 to 1” quad ruled book, which I can get for $2.68 at the Barnes and Noble in the U of Michigan Union. The book goes with me everywhere, and I treat it like a classic lab notebook - date and time stamp all the pages, write things down when you possibly can, never tear a page out.

I find that writing things down makes a huge difference in how I remember them. The a2b3 lunch non-summary that I posted earlier today was written in a first draft in the notebook. The practice is informed a lot by writing things into Twitter - you don’t have much space so you have to be crisp and concise.

Unlike Twitter, I also get to do little sketches and drawings in the notebooks. I miss that ability to do freehand drawings in a quad ruled environment where it’s easy to make a shape that makes sense. My hand-drawing skills are much better than my computer drawing skills, and that means that some part of things I want to capture have to be written down with ink on paper first (and maybe later or maybe never digitized).
